loans.name: Victor

texts.en:
Victor sells clothes and accessories. He stared the business with the help of a brother who provided some merchandise for him to get off the ground. At first he only sold cloths and plastics door-to-door and now he has opened a store where he sells all types of clothing and accessories. Victor is planning to break into the household appliances market with this loan. He will use the capital to invest in microwaves and small kitchens that are very popular in the sector. He believes that there is high demand for these products in his area and that his investment will be successful. Victor is very confident that things go well and he will be able to provide a better future for his three kids.

Mifex offers its clients microinsurance and access to business training and educational programs. For more information about microfinance, Ecuador, and our services, please visit www.mifex.org.

loans.use: Begin selling household appliances

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine andmore clothes stock for his tailoring business

loans.name: Paula

texts.es:
Paula is a 52-year-old married mother of six. Her husband makes bricks and sells them to construction companies. Paula runs a small convenience store out of here home, selling items like sugar, rice, coffee and tortillas. She belongs to a collective along with two other women who make and sell specialty foods who are requesting the loan together to purchase supplies. Additionally, Paula wants to enlarge her store and have it serve as her neighborhood's grocery store.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

PAULA TIENE 52 AÑOS, CASADA , SEIS HIJOS SU ESPOSO TRABAJA HACIENDO LADRILLOS LOS QUE POSTERIORMENTE VENDE PARA LA CONSTRUCCION. PAULA TIENE EN SU CASA UNA MINI TIENDA DE ABARROTES CON LAS COSAS MAS VENDIBLES DENTRO DE SUS VECINAS TALES COMO AZUCAR , ARROZ , CAFÉ , TORTILLAS.PERTENECE AL GRUPO JUSTO JUEZ 3 JUNTO CON LAS SEÑORAS : URSULA CELIA GOMEZ M. ( VENDE EN SU CASA MASAS RELLENAS CON BISTECK, POLLO O PUERCO , LLAMADOS TACOS ) Y MATILDE VERONICA PANIAGUA ROM (HACE PASTELITOS Y LOS SALE A VENDER DE CASA EN CASA ) CON EL PRESTAMO QUIEREN URSULA Y MATILDE COMPRAR MAS MATERIA PRIMA PARA HACER SUS PRODUCTOS Y TAMBIEN UTENSILIOS DE COCINA PARA AUMENTAR LA PRODUCCION Y ASI PODER VENDER EN SUS CASA EN PEQUEÑOS NEGOCITOS. PAULA QUIERE AGRANDAR SU MININEGOCIO Y ESTABLECERSE CON UNA TIENDA DE ABARROTES EN SU COMUNIDAD

loans.use: Purchase supplies and enlarge convenience store

loans.name: Uzma

texts.en:
“After my husband’s death, my three sons started working while I stayed at home to look after my three young daughters. My eldest son plays the keyboard with a group of musicians whenever they can get gigs or shows. The shows pay sufficiently well but since he does not have his own keyboard, my son has to part with half his earnings to pay for renting the instruments. With a loan, I could invest in a keyboard for my son and with the increased monthly income, he could help send his sisters to school.”

Uzma R., Pakistan

loans.use: To buy a keyboard for my son

loans.name: Muminakhon

texts.ru:
Muminakhon H. is married, has a university degree and is the mother of two school-going children. Her husband is a teacher. She also works as a teacher and in her spare time she sells food and electronics at a market stall. Her husband runs the stall when she is teaching. She started selling food to supplement her income because teachers have very low salaries. After getting her first loan Muminakhon increased her sales, added clients and also added electronics to her inventory. Today her assets have doubled in value. She plans to use the new loan to open another market stall.

P.S. The photo is of her husband.

Translated from Russian by Olga Espira, Kiva volunteer.

Хабибуллоева Муминахон замужем, мать двоих детей, образование высшее. Муж работает учителем, дети учатся в школе. Она занимается реализацией продуктов питания, также работает учительницей. Муж заменяет её во время её работы. Начала заниматься торговлей, поскольку зарплата учителей очень мизерная. После получения займа и целевого использования она величила товарооборот, приобрела много клиентов, добавила в свой ассортимент технику. Сейчас её активы возросли в два раза, и в будущем она планирует открыть ещё одну торговую точку. На фото её муж.

loans.use: To open another market stall

loans.name: Ines Maria

texts.en:
Ines is forty-five years old, and she and her husband have five children, including four girls. Her husband is a truck driver and Ines sells cooking provisions throughout her neighborhood. Ines travels the main road in her community wheeling a cart full of fruits, vegetables, and other cooking supplies.

Ines plans on using her loan to purchase a small flatbed truck for use in both transporting and dispensing her goods. Also, she plans to increase her inventory of products, purchasing more of the potatoes and onions that are sought by her customers. Ines believes those investments will be a big step in ensuring her business’s continued growth and the well-being of her family.

loans.use: Purchase of a small flatbed truck for transporting fruits and vegetables

location.town: Sabana Grande de Boya Community of Yamasa

loans.name: Maota

texts.en: Maota is 63 years of age and the mother of 7 children. She is the one that always gives support to her husband and two sons by operating their taro plantation six days a week. She hardly asks her family living overseas for financial support because she takes 3-4 bags of taro to the market twice a week and she earns more than $300.00-$400.00 ($120-160 USD) a month. To keep her children in school and to extend her 4 acre taro plantation is the reason she is applying for another loan from the SPBD Program.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies for her plantation

loans.name: Nabaziza A (Iii) Group

texts.en: This group has been together for one year. Marx sells livestock. Teo is a livestock farmer and wants to use the loan to buy a calf. Berna has a poultry business and intends to purchase more broilers. Jane has a photo studio and wants to use the loan to buy a generator. Ruth owns a small bar.

loans.use: To add in firewood business

loans.name: Ramatu

texts.en:
Ramatu is 27 years old and married with three children. Ramatu said her business has increased after joining the SMT program. With the profit, she bought a dressing mirror and beds for her children.

Her plan is to expand her business for more income so that she can support her elderly parents. Ramatu’s regular income is insufficient to support the family expenses so her business supplements that.

She is requesting a loan for $525 (Le.1,500,000) to expand the business.

loans.use: Ramatu needs to buy additional supplies of shoes to sell in her shop, and additional capital would help her to do so.

loans.name: Ashurby

texts.ru:
Ashurby N. lives in the city of Vahdat. She is 55 years old, married and has 12 children. She has a High School education. She is currently self-employed. She is in the business of celling groceries. She has a sales location not far from her house. The profit from her business is the main source of income for her family. This money is just enough to feed her large family. Ashurby would like to increase turnover, but in order to do that she needs additional financing. This is the reason why she is seeking to borrow additional funds. She is planing to repay the loan withing a 9 months period.

Translated from Russian by Jane Mazur, Kiva volunteer

Насриддинова Ашурби жительница города Вахдат. Ей 55 лет , она замужем , имеет 12 детей. Образование среднее. Закончила 9 классов средней школы. Нигде не работает , но занимается бизнесом. Имеет торговую точку рядом с домом. Торгует продуктами питания. Ее бизнес дает небольшой доход , дающий возможность только скромно кормить свою семью.Не смотря на это этот бизнес является основным источником дохода ее семьи. Ашурби хочет увеличить свой товарооборот, путем дополнительного финансирования. Но это возможно только при помощи кредита. Поэтому клиентка обратилась к нам за помощью. Погасить кредит клиентка планирует в течении 9 месяцев.

loans.use: Increase the diversity of goods for sale

loans.name: Amparo Del Socorro

texts.es:
Amparo A., 58 years old, is a kind woman who lives in Villa Venezuela. She is a widow and has four grown children, whose ages range from 19 to 32. To help her children get ahead, she started working from her house more than 30 years ago as a seamstress. She started her business by purchasing a used sewing machine, which she still owns, with her savings.

Her children married and became independent, and she now lives alone in her humble home with walls made of zinc. Her dream is for her business to prosper and to make improvements to her small house. She seeks a loan for the working capital necessary to purchase fabric to make clothing to sell.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Amparo A. de 58 años de edad, es una amable mujer que habita en Villa Venezuela, es viuda y tiene 4 hijos ya mayores de edad, de 32 y 19 años, para sacar adelante a sus hijos desde hace mas de 30 años trabaja en su casa de habitación como costurera, negocio que inició comprando una máquina usada con sus ahorros, la cual aun conserva. Sus hijos se casaron e independizaron y ella quedó sola viviendo en una humilde casita cuyas paredes son de Zinc, su sueño es que su negocio prospere y pueda mejorar su casita. Solicita un préstamo para capital de trabajo ya que necesita comprar telas y hacer ropa para la venta

loans.use: Purchase fabrics for her sewing.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy used women's clothing

loans.name: Hadisa

texts.ru:
Hadisa A. is a tailor. She sews traditional women's clothing. She had been in this business for the past 5 years. Currently, she has only one sewing machine. There is a demand for her products, and that is why she wants to open a mini tailor shop. To do that, she needs to purchase more textiles and an additional sewing machine. This will help her to increase efficiency and, in turn, profits. Hadisa is 25 years old, divorced, and has 4 children. She is the sole provider for her family. For this reason, she needs to develop her business. Moreover, many residents of her town use her services. To achieve her goals, she decided to apply for a loan, which will solve many of her problems. She is planning to pay it off within the next 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Vasilisa Budnikova, Kiva Volunteer.

Ачилова Хадиса –портниха . Шьет национальную женскую одежду. Работает уже 5 лет . Имеет дома одну швейную машинку. Работа идет. Но она хочет открыть миниателье. Поэтому ей необходимо закупить сырье и еще одну швейную машинку. Это поможет ей ускорить темп работы и соответственно увеличить доход. Хадисе 25 лет , она разведена и имеет четверых детей. Весь груз по обеспечению семьи лежит на ней. Поэтому она должна развивать свое дело. Кроме того ее услугами пользуется весь кишлак в котором она живет. Поэтому для того , чтобы достичь этой цели она решила получить кредит , который и решит ее проблемы . Погасить кредит сможет в течении 10 месяцев.

loans.use: To purchase textiles and sewing machine

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet is a 46-year-old widow with three children who are in school. She is a very hard-working and resourceful mother. She is a retailer of charcoal in her neighborhood. Charcoal is a very popular source of energy for cooking in almost all the traditional Ghanaian homes. Janet obtains her supply of charcoal from the surrounding villages of Koforidua and retails them to her customers. She wants to use the loan to buy bulk supply of charcoal to retail to her customers. She hopes to increase her savings to pay for her children’s educational fees. She belongs to the community group called “Nyame ye odo” (God is love) Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as a social collateral to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy bulk supply of charcoal.

loans.name: Edith Namirembe's Group

texts.en:
Edith is a leader of 4 members of a group. She is a 33-year-old married woman with 5 children. They are aged between 3 and 17 years. Four are in school.

She rents a 2-room house in which she lives with 6 people. There is piped water and electricity. She resides and works in a semi-urban and slum area, which is in the outskirts of Kampala.

Edith works 7 days a week and has a retail shop. She buys her merchandise from Kampala twice a week and uses public transport. Her customers are the people of her community and those passing through.

Edith's challenges include paying high taxes, high rental charges, and high transport costs. Flooding during the rainy season is yet another challenge, as the area where she is operating is prone to floods, and this destroys her merchandise. She has been operating this business for the last 5 years and was inspired by the other shopkeepers around, and she has been able to pay school fees for her children and also improve her standard of living.

Her main inspiration is owning a permanent house/home so that she can stop paying rent. She would also want to see her business progress.

loans.use: To increase stock

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok P., 29,  who is married and resides in Kampong Cham, Cambodia, has been growing sugar cane for a living since 2000, earning about $4 each day. Her husband, Nal Nom, typically makes around $2.50 each day as a construction worker building houses. This couple has three children, one of whom is a student while the others are too young to attend school. 

Sok is requesting a loan from Kiva via Credit, its local partner, to purchase sugar cane seed to grow for the upcoming season, which is fast approaching.

loans.use: To purchase sugar cane seed to grow for the upcoming season.

loans.name: Maria Candelaria

texts.es:
Maria una persona emprendedora, entusiasta y muy trabajadora. Tiene 3 hijos: Gustavo de 22 años, casado, Andrés de 20 años, trabaja y Edith de 18 años, casada. Su esposo trabaja como operador de grua.Ella inició el negocio porque siempre le han gustado las ventas y también la elaboración de manualidades, decidio aprovechar esas habilidades que tiene para iniciar su propio negocio. Comenzó en el mes de Enero de 2000 en un mercado rodante, con la venta de ropa usada ya que a su cuñada le iba bien y fue ella quien la convenció, ya que a ella, le mandaban pacas de ropa y a muy buen precio de las ciudades fronterizas de Reynosa y Matamoros. Tambien se dedica a hacer manualidades, tiene mucho mas tiempo, desde que era jovencita, su abuelita le enseñó a hacer flores y coronas de papel encerado para el día de muertos, y después ella fue aprendiendo a hacer otro tipo de adornos, sobre todo navideños, guiándose por revistas que compraba, así que ahora elabora todo ese tipo de manualidades dependiendo la época del año en que este, como Navidad, día de muertos, día de las madres, etc. El crédito anterior que recibio a través de KIVA le ayudó muchísimo ya que pude comprar ropa y materiales para sus manualidades y pude tener buenas ventas en la época de navidad de 2007.

Ella necesita un prestamo por US $325 que pagara en 5 meses para comprar más pacas de ropa usada y materiales para elaborar manualidades navideñas y tener una mayor variedad de productos para ofrecer a los clientes.
texts.en:
Maria is an enterprising, enthusiastic, and hard-working woman. She has 3 children; Gustavo, who is 22 years old and married, Andrés, who is 20 years old and works, and Edith, who is 18 years old and is married. Maria's husband works as a crane operator. She began her business because she she has always liked sales and making crafts, and she decided to take advantage of these two abilities. In January of 2000 she began selling used clothing in a traveling market, because her mother-in-law did the same, and had experienced success in doing so. This same mother-in-law sent Maria clothing at a good price from the border cities of Reynosa and Matamoros. Maria also makes crafts, and has been doing so since she was a little girl. Her grandmother taught her how to make paper flowers and crowns for the Day of the Dead and later Maria went on to learn to make other types of adornments, mostly Christmas ornaments, which she learned from magazines. She made all types of adornments depending on the season, for holidays such as Christmas, Day of the Dead, Mother's day, etc. The previous loan that she received through KIVA helped her to purchase clothing and materials to make crafts, and to have good sales during the 2007 Christmas season. Maria needs a $325 loan which she will repay in 5 months to purchase more clothing and materials to make Christmas ornaments, so that she can offer a wider variety of products to her clients.

Translated from Spanish by Jordan Shanker, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase materials to make Christmas ornaments to sell

loans.name: Kafui

texts.fr: Kafui T. est propriétaire d’une boutique d’alimentation générale de puis 2 ans. Agée de 26 ans, elle est mariée et mère d’un petit garçon. Elle souhaite redynamiser son activité en s’approvisionnant en marchandises qui lui permettra d’accroître son chiffre d’affaires et par là, ses profits et par conséquent une amélioration des conditions de vie de la famille.
texts.en:
Kafui T., 26, has been the owner of a general store for 2 years. She is married and the mother of a little boy. She is hoping to reinvigorate her business by buying merchandise for re-sale that will help her to increase her turnover and thus, her profit, so that she can improve living conditions for her family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of merchandise for re-sale

loans.name: Edmy

texts.es:
Edmy se dedica a la comercialización de vajilla ( en ingles “china”) en general y los vende a crédito como también tiene una pequeña tienda de dulces y refrescos en una cancha de wally (deporte parecido al volley ball) que es de su propiedad en su mismo domicilio.
Vive en la zona de Pampahasi de la ciudad de La Paz; tiene dos hijos en edad universitaria que solo se dedican a estudiar y dependen de ella. El crédito será destinado a la compra de mercadería y tener un buen stock para las fiestas de navidad.
Es la primera vez que solicita un crédito en Impro, sus ganas de superarse y de trabajar le dan la oportunidad para obtener este crédito.
texts.en:
Edmy sells china in general, which she sells on credit. She also has a small stand of sweets and refreshments on a “wally” court (wally is a sport similar to volley ball) that is on the property on which she also lives. She lives in the zone Pampahasi of the city La Paz. She has two children of college age that strictly dedicate themselves to studying and depend on her. The loan will be used to buy merchandise and to have a good stock for Christmas festivities. This is the first time that she is asking for a loan with Impro. Her desire to better herself and to work legitimize granting this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Matt Capetola, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy china for her sale during the Christmas season and the New Year.

loans.name: João

texts.pt:
João B. é natural de Maputo e tem 42 anos de idade, casado e pai de 2 filhos ainda estudantes, para alem dos filhos sustenta uma prima que vive com ela.

João estudou até 10ªclasse e parou quando perdeu o seu pai e não tinha alguém para o custear os estudos, assim viu se obrigado a procurar emprego para o seu sustenta e mais tarde tirou o curso de professor primário e neste momento dá aulas. Funcionário do estado e tem um salário mensal de 4600,00mt.

Para João este é o terceiro empréstimo na Hluvuku e primeiro no Kiva com qual pretende continuar com a construção da sua obra. Desta maneira diz que vai procurar pagar antes do tempo para voltar solicitar outro empréstimo de forma a concluir mais rápido a sua casa.
texts.en:
João B. is a native of Maputo. He is 42 years old, married, and the father of 2 children who are both still students. Besides his children he also supports a cousin who lives with them. João studied until the 10th grade and stopped when he lost his father and had no one to pay for the costs of his schooling. As such he was obliged to search for work to sustain himself. Later he took a course to teach elementary school, and now he teaches classes. He is an employee of the state, and he earns a monthly salary of 4,600MT. This is João's third loan through Hluvuku and his first with Kiva. He intends to use the proceeds to continue with the construction on his home. In this way he says he will try to pay off the loan before the term so he can return and borrow another loan with the hopes of finishing his home more quickly.

Translated from Portuguese by Jared Wandry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction materials

loans.name: Modesta

texts.es:
La señora Modesta A. vive en casa propia, en la zona  de Callapa, zona peri urbana de la ciudad de La Paz, con su esposo, el señor Celso Aduviri y sus dos hijos.
La señora Modesta elabora mantas de vicuña y alpaca que vende de casa en casa y su esposo recolecta arena del río próximo a su vivienda, que vende a las construcciones privadas.
Recientemente adquirieron la propiedad en la que viven actualmente y de la que eran cuidadores, para lo que utilizaron sus ahorros.
El crédito que ahora Modesta solicita es para la compra de lana para elaborar sus mantas, ya que su capital fue invertido en la compra de su vivienda.
Esta es la cuarta vez que solicita préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado la califican favorablemente y puede acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Modesta A. lives in her own house, in the Callapa zone just outside La Paz city, with her husband Celso Aduviri and their two children. Modesta makes blankets from vicuña and alpaca wool and sells them door-to-door. Her husband gathers sand from the river near their house, which he sells to construction companies. They recently acquired the property where they live now, using their savings to buy it. The loan Modesta is requesting will be used to buy wool to make her blankets, as she used the rest of her money to invest in her home. This is her fourth loan request and the analysis of her application qualified her to received another loan.

Translated from Spanish by Vivian Lu, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of vicuña and alpaca wool to make blankets.

loans.name: Tara

texts.en:
Mrs. Tara D., 31 years old, is a tailor in the town of Kritpur.  She opened her tailoring shop 3 years ago. Her specialty is making custom-fitted ladies' dresses like the Kurta Sulwar, which is very popular with Nepali women. Before starting her own business, Mrs D. took a 6-month training course in tailoring from a tailor shop near her home.
She plans to use the Rs. 20,000.00 loan to buy raw materials for her tailoring work. She wants to use the shop's income for self-improvement and for her son’s education. In Nepal, the cost of good education is increasing, and Mrs. D. is saving her income to provide a good education for her son.

loans.use: To buy tailoring materials

loans.name: Mubina

texts.en:
Mubina F. is a 35-year-old married mother of three children. Mubina is a teacher, but as her salary is small, she has also run her own grocery business for the last six years. Mubina wishes to increase her business and offer an increased range of foodstuffs to her customers. Her aim is to provide the best possible example and way of life for her beloved children, who are the reason for her daily efforts and the apple of her eye. With this opportunity and her desire to succeed, she is appealing to your generosity and requesting a loan of $1000 USD. She promises to repay the loan within 12 months. By supporting Mubina you can be an important link in the growth of this business. More about Tajikistan Tajikistan, a key post on the Silk Road, is perhaps best known for its rich history. It was the location for the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and is known for its great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country, with its epic mountain passes, is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mix of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the USSR, damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 per cent of the country is mountainous and only 7 per cent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands of people to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. More about IMON Interational Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase an increased range of foodstuffs

loans.name: Adamu

texts.en:
Adamu I. is 38 years old. He is a married man with three children. Adamu says as a married man, he needs to work very hard to make some income to provide for the family. He lives with his wife and children in a rented apartment in Mampong, in the Ashanti Region of Ghana.

Adamu owns a poultry farm. He procures birds – chicks, layers and broilers from dealers in nearby communities. He sells matured birds at the local market on market days. Adamu also treks to sell in markets in nearby communities.

He has been in business for three years and wants a loan to procure more birds. He is hopeful to expand his business.

loans.use: Procure more birds.

loans.name: Hope Group

texts.en:
This is Fannyann D., Dowu W., Eugenia B., Aminata M., Augustine N. and Ened Y.. They named their group Hope. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are requesting from SMT/Kiva. Each of them is requesting a loan of Le 500,000.00. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses. 

Fannyann D. (left) is the leader of this group. Fannyann is 49 years of age. She was born in Hastings, 20 miles from Freetown. She is single with four children. One of her children is already a grown-up and the other three are still in school. Fannyann is a poultry owner. She will invest this loan into her poultry business by increasing her stock of chickens. She has been in this business for six years now.

loans.use: Expand her business by adding to her stock of chickens

loans.name: Carlos Jose

texts.es: Don Carlos José A., tiene 53 años de edad, reside en Sabana Grande, en la capital de Managua, su esposa le tiene tres hermosos hijos los cuales cursan la secundaria, su esposa trabaja en un almacén para compartir los gastos y dar estudios a sus hijos, el se desempeña como cadete en la ciudad de Managua desde hace ocho años, este es su cuarto ciclo en Afodenic que espera seguir trabajando para obtener los beneficios que hasta ahora ha tenido para su familia. Con este crédito lo quiere para construir parte del baño y poder gozar de mejores condiciones. Sus metas a largo plazo es poder tener su propio vehiculo que le sea rentable.
texts.en:
Don Carlos José A. is 53 years old, and lives in Sabana Grande, in the capital Managua. He and his wife have three beautiful children who are in secondary school. His wife works in a grocery store to share the expenses and to pay for their childrens' studies. He has been doing well as a cadet in the city of Managua for eight years. This is his fourth cycle in Afodenic and he hopes to continue working to obtain the benefits that he has had up until now for his family. He would like this loan to construct part of a bathroom and to be able to enjoy better conditions. His long term goal is to be able to have his own vehicle which will be profitable for him.

Translated from Spanish by Heather Nicholson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction materials to make a bathroom

loans.name: Maximiliana

texts.es:
Maximiliana es socia del Banco Comunal La Kantuta.
Maximiliana es separada, tiene 48 años y 5 hijos, Maximiliana vende ropa en las diferentes ferias de la región, actividad que realiza con la ayuda de sus hijos, y los días domingos vende en la feria dominical de las Américas.
Maximiliana necesita un préstamo de 2100 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de pantalones, casacas.
Los sueños de Maximiliana son educar a sus hijos y construir su casa.
texts.en:
Maximiliana is a member of the community bank "La Kantuta."

Maximiliana is separated, is 48 years old, and has 5 children. She sells clothing in the different markets in her region, something she has been doing with the help of her children. On Sundays, she sells in the Americas market. Maximiliana seeks this loan of 2100 Peruvian soles in order to invest in the purchase of pants and jackets.

She dreams of providing an education for her children and building her home.

Translated from Spanish by Michelle Harrison, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of pants and jackets

loans.name: Adèle

texts.fr: S. Adèle est née le 10/05/1968 à Cotonou, Capitale Économique  de la République du Bénin. Mais Adèle est originaire d'Agonlin dans le Département du Mono. Adèle est mariée à ODOUTAN  Simplice, mécanicien vélomoteur. Adèle et Simplice ont deux enfants Mohammed et Iswath tous scolarisés. Adèle vit avec sa famille au quartier Agontinkon à Cotonou. Adèle a eu un bref cursus scolaire et alla après en apprentissage de couture. Avant la fin de sa formation, Adèle abandonna la couture pour faire de petits commerces. Actuellement, Adèle vend des fruits d'avocat de façon ambulante. Adèle a déjà eu deux crédits de ALIDé pour développer son activité de vente de fruits d'avocat. Adèle veut diversifier son activité avec la vente de chaussures et tissus en provenance de Lomé, Capitale du Togo, pays frontalier au Bénin. C'est la raison pour laquelle Adèle sollicite un troisième prêt de ALIDé.
texts.en:
S. Adèle was born on May 10, 1968 in Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Benin. But she traces her roots to Agonlin in Mono County. She is married to ODOUTAN Simplice, a motorbike mechanic. Adèle and Simplice have two children, Mohammed and Iswath who are both in school. Adèle lives with her family in the Agontinkon in Cotonou. She attended school for a short time and afterwards entered into a sewing apprenticeship. Before completing her training, she dropped sewing for working in a small business. Currently, she sells avocados door-to-door. Adèle has already had two Alidé loans for developing her business selling avocados. She wants to diversify her business with the sale of shoes and cloth from Lomé, the capital of Togo, a country bordering Benin. This is why she’s requesting her third loan from Alidé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 36 pairs of shoes and ten 12-meter bolts of Hitarget cloth

loans.name: Hasifa's Group

texts.en:
N. Hasifa is the leader of Balikudembe group in Buwola. She is a polite woman and a married mother of 5 children aged 14-2 years, of whom 4 are in primary school. She is a business-lady selling "nakati" (green vegetables) that she grows in her gardens; she also keeps sheep and goats for meat and wants to expand her farm.

Her customers for the green vegetables are located all over Lugazi and she is lucky that her customers come to her for the purchases, hence allowing her to save on transport. She is able to make weekly profits of 30,000/= per week (minus the sale of animals). Hasifa needs a loan to top up with her current savings and buy another piece of land to expand her farming.

loans.use: Buying a plot of land to expand her farming

loans.name: Nawal

texts.en:
Nawal is a very active women in Biet Sahour. Her husbend passed away a few years ago, so she has a big burden to raise her two sons. Nawal decided to open her own clothing shop and not to depend on anyone. Now she has a clothing shop in downtown Beit Sahour; her business is going very well and she depends on herself to raise her children, not requesting assistance from anyone. She approached FATEN to take a 3000 USD loan to expand her business and to have more product variety at her shop, specially since during the summer there are a lot of happy occasions for families: weddings, graduation, etc.

Nawal appears at her shop in the picture.

loans.use: Purchase clothes for the shop

loans.name: Phun

texts.en:
Mrs. K. Phun, 23, and her husband, Mr. Savun Pork, 33, live in a small village across the Mekong River, about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 2001 and have three sons: one attends school, and the other two are still young and stay at home.

Since five years, K. has been into silk weaving, a skill she learned from her neighbor. Her husband is also a silk weaver. They sell their finished products to a middle man in the village, who in turn sells in the Phnom Penh market.

K. is requesting her first loan of $400 to purchase silk material for their silk-weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for their silk-weaving business

loans.name: Nodirbek

texts.en:
A. Nodirbek is an energetic young man who tries every single day to make the life of his family better. Nodirbek started his business six years ago. He is carrying on the business of his father, who is now a pensioner. Nodirbek has great experience in cattle breeding because he has observed the process since childhood.

Nodirbek would like to expand his business and purchase more calves. This will help him to increase income and improve his family's living conditions.

We wish him good luck and appreciate your help!

More about Tajikistan

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road and being the location of the end of the rule of Alexander the Great. It is also known for its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets, such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi, and many others. The country, filled with epic mountain passes, is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, and boasts a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture, and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 percent of the country is mountainous and only seven percent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

More about IMON International

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase cattle in order to expand the business

loans.name: Xenia

texts.es: Xenia tiene 34 años, vive en la casa de sus padres, con ellos y sus sobrinos. Desde hace más de 3 años se dedica a la venta de cosméticos y joyas a sus compañeras de trabajo, pues ella es profesora en una escuela de su localidad. Con sus clientes, Xenia pacta un acuerdo de pago al crédito y según lo convenido, ella les entrega el producto y posteriormente les cobra. De este modo, aparte de su remuneración como docente, obtiene las ganancias que necesita para  solventar sus gastos personales y de su familia. Su deseo a futuro es seguir dedicándose a la venta de cosméticos, pero en un local estable con una decoración atractiva y en una zona comercial de su ciudad. Esta es la quinta vez que tiene un crédito con MFP, ella es una de las integrantes que promueve la responsabilidad en su banco comunal y esta vez renueva su compromiso de trabajo y puntualidad en sus pagos. El dinero que viene solicitando será invertido en la compra de  productos de belleza para incrementar sus ventas.

loans.use: Incremento de mercadería

loans.name: Tamaraneh Traders Group

texts.en:
Here are Memuna T., Kadiatu S., Adama T., Zainab S. and Marie K.. They are members of the Tamaraneh Traders group. This will be the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva. They have been in business for many years now but business has been developing at a very slow pace. They have thus come to SMT/Kiva to seek a loan of 500,000 Sierra Leonean leone for each to help them improve their businesses. 

Memuna T. (pictured on the left) is the leader of this group. Memuna was born in the village of Mayolo, on the outskirts of Magburaka town, about 55 years ago. She is married with nine children: five are already grown-ups, one is in Junior Secondary School III (JSS III), while the others are in JSS II, JSS I and class I. 

Memuna owns a small kiosk in Mayolo village where she sells stuff like cigarettes, biscuits, batteries, mints, lighters, etc. Memuna has been a businesswoman since her childhood days. She will use this loan to expand her business, as she believes that the bigger the business capital, the faster the business will grow.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Good News Group

texts.en: Eva is thirty – one years old. She is married and has given birth to two children, both in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Dormaa in the Brong Ahafo Region of Ghana. Dormaa is a commercial and farming town. Eva is a trader. She trades in printed textile materials. She is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Good News’. The group is made of mostly traders and food vendors. Some hawk to sell in their community while others also trek to nearby communities to sell. The group wants a loan to help them buy goods in bulk to increase their stock. The group leader, Eva is seated right in the photograph.

loans.use: To buy stock

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en: Juliana is a 31-year-old woman. She is married and has three children: two are in school and her youngest is breastfeeding. She lives with her husband. Juliana is an achiever and a resourceful mother.  Juliana has been in the business of selling foodstuffs, like plantains, for ten years now and loves it. She treks to surrounding villages in the community to purchase bulk stock of plantains from the farmers and sells them retail to her customers. For lack of adequate working capital, she is not able to pick enough stock to make enough profit to support her family.  With the loan, she wants to purchase bulk supplies of plantains to enable her to scale up her business.

loans.use: To purchase plantains in bulk

loans.name: Abdel Karim

texts.en:
Abdel Karim is a 30-year-old man who lives in Tripoli, northern Lebanon, with his wife and their two children. Abdel Karim sells all kinds of birds. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase bird food and different bird breeds. This is his second loan cycle and he has paid on time. His previous loan helped him improve his business.

Abdel Karim is special in his work because he knows how to treat his clients. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties because he took after his father’s work. Abdel Karim wants to improve his income and he plans on expanding.

loans.use: To purchase bird food and different bird breeds.

loans.name: Wilson Nyabwari

texts.en:
Wilson Nyabwari O., 30 years old, is married and has two children. He has sold utensils, cookery and household items for the last four years. His customers are walk-ins and the local customers near market stalls. He has no employees but does face strong competition from similar businesses.

Wilson is using the proceeds of the KES 20,000 loan to buy sufurias (pots), mugs and padlocks.

Apart from this business, Wilson also does subsistence farming. In the future, he wants to own a hardware store. He describes himself as hardworking and focused.

loans.use: To buy twelve sets of sufurias, ten dozen mugs and one box of padlocks

loans.name: Luz Maria

texts.es:
La señora  LUZ MARIA R. S. tiene 45 años, vive en el distrito de EL PORVENIR, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad – Perú y pertenece al Banco Comunal LIDERESAS EN ACCIÒN.
La socia tiene estudios secundarios completos, tiene 2 hijos, de los cuales uno depende económicamente de ella.
Luz se dedica al cuidado de 8 niños en el wawawasi que tiene en la casa de su hermana y paralelamente a la cría de cuyes para la venta los fines de semana en el mercado cercano a su casa.
Con su primer crédito de 300.00 nuevos soles compró alimentos para los cuyes y también vasos, tazas, jarras para el wawawasi.
Con su próximo crédito de 300.00 nuevos soles comprará alimento para los cuyes como: engorde, panca, 1 saco de alimento balanceado y alfalfa.
Luz sueña con tener una tienda de comestibles en su casa para así generar mayores ingresos en la familia.
texts.en:
Sra. Luz Maria R. S. is 45 years old and lives in the District of El Porvenir, Trujillo Province, Department of La Libertad – Perú. She is a member of the Communal Bank “Lideresas en Acción” (Leaders in Action). Luz completed her high school education and has two dependent children.

Luz takes care of 8 children at the day care center she operates at her sister’s house. At the same time, she raises guinea pigs to sell on the weekends at the market near her house. Her first loan of 300 soles was used to buy feed for her guinea pigs as well as glasses, cups, and pitchers for her day care center. With this next loan of 300 soles, she will buy food to fatten her guinea pigs, such as corn husks, alfalfa, and 1 sack of nutritional feed.

Luz dreams of opening a grocery store in her home so that she can generate more income for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase food for her guinea pigs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase embroidery materials

loans.name: Koubouratou

texts.fr: Cette dame est une veuve qui a un enfant à sa charge, l’activité génératrice de revenu  qu’elle exerce pour subvenir à ses charges et  à celles de son enfant est le commerce de détail de produits génériques auquel elle a associé le commerce de détail de trousseaux de bébé. Elle exerce son commerce dans le marché local  d’agoè. Son stock a diminué, pour se réapprovisionner elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de 06 cartons de produits génériques et 13 douzaines de trousseaux de bébé.
texts.en:
This lady is a widow with one child under her care. To meet her own needs and those of her child, she generates revenue through the retail of generic products, to which she has added the retail of baby layettes. She runs her business in the local market, Agoé. She needs to replenish her decreasing stock of merchandise, and therefore requests a loan from WAGES to buy six boxes of generic products and 13 dozen baby layettes.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy generic products and baby layettes

loans.name: Sema

texts.en:
Sema J. is currently in the business of selling groundnut paste and charcoal in the market and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  Sema is 37 years old and is married to a driver. She has six children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to purchase a taxi.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more bags of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Nueva Luz De Pachaquillay Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal NUEVA LUZ DE PACHAQUILLAY está formado por 9 socios, inician su tercer ciclo y son trabajadores que buscan a cada momento las oportunidades para salir adelante y con su esfuerzo diario entregar un mejor futuro a sus hijos, las socias viven en la comunidad de Pachaquillay de la provincia de Anta del departamento del Cusco, ciudad que se caracteriza por sus paisajes hermosos, su agricultura y su ganadería. La cuidad Anta se encuentra ubicado a una media hora de la Ciudad del Cusco. Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como la venta de comida, venta de artesanía, venta de granos y venta de ganado, otros socios brindan servicios como construcción de casas. Los socios que tienen negocios están preocupados porque las ventas han disminuido debido a las fuertes lluvias que cayeron por tres días en la ciudad del Cusco pues hicieron que clientes cancelaron sus viajes a la ciudad de Pachaquillay y ahora los socios están tratando de recuperar las ventas perdidas.    
     
Edgar es socio del banco comunal “Nueva luz de Pachaquillay”, tiene 31 años de edad, es conviviente y su esposa se llama Yovana, ellos se dedican a la compra y venta de árboles de eucalipto. El socio requiere el préstamo para comprar más árboles de Eucaliptos. 
   
Los socios en general agradecen la oportunidad brindada y se comprometen a cumplir con el pago de sus diferentes cuotas en los plazos establecidos.
texts.en:
The NUEVA LUZ DE PACHAQUILLAY communal bank is made up of 9 members who are starting their 3rd loan cycle. They are workers who always seek opportunities to succeed and to provide a better future for their children through their hard work. The members reside in Pachaquillay, Anta province, Cusco department; a city that is noted for its beautiful scenery, its agriculture and its cattle raising. The city of Anta is half an hour away from the city of Cusco. The members are involved in various commercial activities, such as: food sales, crafts sales, grain and cattle sales. Others provide services like home construction. The members who have businesses are worried because sales have declined due to the heavy rains that fell on Cusco for three days. This caused many travelers to cancel their trips to Pachaquillay and now the members are trying to recuperate their losses. Edgar is a member of the “Nueva Luz de Pachaquillay” communal bank. He is 31 years old, lives with his life partner, Yovana. They are eucalyptus tree merchants. He needs funding to buy more eucalyptus trees. The members, in general, are grateful for the opportunity provided and pledge to repay in a timely fashion.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy more eucalyptus trees.

loans.name: Jada Virginia

texts.es:
La señora Jada Virginia L. C. es casada tiene un hijo menor de edad a su cargo, habita en el municipio de el Viejo con la familia de el esposo, es profesora de primaria en el  Centro Educativo Jesús de Nazareth desde hace ocho años.
La señora Jada L. C. solicito este financiamiento para completar para comprar un pequeño solar ya que actualmente vive en casa de su suegra y desea superarse poco a poco con la ayuda de su esposo y su esfuerzo propio.
texts.en:
Jada Virginia L. C. is married and has a minor son under her care; she lives in the El Viejo municipality with her in-laws. She has been an elementary school teacher at Jesús de Nazareth educational center for 8 years. She requested this loan in order to purchase a small lot because she currently lives in her mother-in-law's house and she wants to improve herself gradually with her husband's help and through her own efforts.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a lot.

loans.name: Mujeres Alegres Group

texts.es:
Este grupo del Barrio Arroyo Porá  surgió por contacto de una de las integrantes con la fundación. Cada una de las señoras realiza una actividad diferente e independiente dependiendo de la facilidad con que cuentan.
El comité periódicamente recibe curso de capacitación de parte de las asesoras de la Fundación, con esto ellas aprenden muchas cosas de como manejar especialmente la economía familiar planificando todas las actividades.
La señora Maria T. es una de las integrantes y se dedica a la venta de ropa en un salón que abrió en su casa, ella cuenta con todo tipo de prendas de vestir y ofrece a muy buen precio a sus clientes, el salón es atendida por ella y por su hija quien le ayuda con las labores.
Ella nos comenta que el negocio ayuda mucho especialmente con los gastos escolares de sus hijos, y desea que el negocio se mantenga y crezca mas cada día.
El crédito que retiro lo utilizó para la compra de todo tipo de prendas de vestir, como camisas, pantalones, vestidos, remeras.
texts.en:
This group from Barrio Arroyo Porá got started when one of the members met someone from the foundation. Each one of the señoras has a different and independent business depending on what facilities they have. The committee receives periodic training from the Foundation's advisers. They learn how to manage and in particular how to manage the families' finances. Señora Maria T. is one of our members and she sells clothing from a salon she opened in her home. She has every type of clothing and offers her customers good prices. She takes of the store with her daughter who helps her. She tells us that her business helps a lot, especially with her kid's school expenses. She hopes the business keeps up and grows daily. She used the loan she took out to buy a variety of clothes like shirts, pants, dresses, and t-shirts.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise, food, clothing, fabric, thread, vegetablers, and otehr supplies to stock kiosks and stalls.

loans.name: Beatha

texts.en:
Beatha is 30 years old, married with five children and she takes care of two dependents.  Beatha has been working as a businesswoman wholesaling a variety of goods mainly cooking oil, rice, sweets, covered water, etc.  She has been in this business for about one year and the hours of her business are from 6 am to 8 pm every day.

Beatha is now requesting a Kiva loan so that she can expand her shop by adding cosmetic goods and increasing the quantity of foodstuffs like sugar, rice, different types of flours and some other goods that seem to be highly demanded in her business area. With this loan, Beatha hopes that she will be able to satisfy the needs of her customers and hopefully her sales will increase as well as her profits.  If successful, she will start saving as well as reinvesting in her business with one portion of the earned profits.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs like sugar, rice and different types of flours

loans.name: Maria Cristina

texts.es: Maria Cristina había solicitado un financiamiento anteriormente, por lo que no es la primera vez que busca esta manera de mejorar su capital. Su esposo  trabaja como chofer por lo que también aporta para el ingreso de la familia. Aduce la señora que ha logrado crecer su negocio y ha logrado obtener mayores utilidades al vender más. Algo que ha influido, es que ella administra su negocio de una buena manera. Lo que la ha afectado, es que constantemente están cambiando el precio de estos productos. Por eso solicita este financiamiento destinado para capital de trabajo así comprara leche, cuajada, queso y crema.
texts.en:
Maria Cristina has applied for financing previously, so this is not the first time that she has sought this way of increasing her capital. Her husband works as a driver, so he also contributes to the income of the family. It is clear that she has succeeded in increasing her business and in obtaining better profits from selling more. One influence on her success is that she administers her business well. Something that affects her is that they are constantly changing the price of these products. For this reason, she is applying for a loan to be used for working capital to buy milk, curds, cheese, and cream.

Translated from Spanish by Pam McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Jessenia Monserrate

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal María José se reúne en la productiva parroquia de Picoaza en la provincia de Manabí en este bellos lugar sus moradores en gran mayoría son comerciantes informales, en diferentes aéreas como el comercio de ropa, hamacas, utensilio del hogar y un sinnúmero de productos.

La señora Jessenia es una de las socia que lleva 6 ciclos en este banco comunal, esta con una relación es madre de dos niños, dedica su tiempo a una guardería comunitaria en la misma parroquia, pero también se da tiempo para tener otros ingresos, que es precisamente la venta de productos de Yanbal, Avon y ropa interior, ya son dos años con las ventas, ella visita a sus clientas en las cosas toma el pedido de los productos, y en la ropa ella viaja a comprar por docenas cada cierto tiempo según como vayan las ventas, con los créditos que ha recibido de la Fundación ha hecho que su negocio crezca, todo lo que es Yanbal y Avon lo compra al contado y la ropa si le dan crédito pagando según como vaya vendiendo, la misma manera ella hace con sus clientes les facilita los pagos.

Con este nuevo crédito que esta solicitando podrá comprar más mercadería y a la vez podrá ayudar al esposo a que surta su negocio, el esposo es comerciante de accesorios de teléfonos celulares, como carcasas, cargadores, y controles de televisores.

El sueño de la señora Jessenia es poder terminar su carrera de Parvularia, esta convencida que lo podrá hacer realidad le gusta mucho trabajar con niños y desde las 8 de la mañana hasta las 4 de la tarde esta en la guardería sus hijos están junto a ella todo el tiempo. Esta contenta con lo que esta haciendo para ayudar a su familia a salir a delante.
texts.en:
The communal bank María José meets in the productive parish of Picoaza in the province of Manabí. The inhabitants of this beautiful place are mainly informal businesspeople. They sell different items such as clothing, hammocks, kitchen utensils and numerous other products. Jessenia is one of the members that has been with the communal bank for six cycles. She is in a relationship and is the mother of two children. She spends her time at a community nursery school in the same parish. She has another source of income selling Yanbal and Avon products and underwear. She has been doing this for two years. She visits her customers in their homes and takes their product orders. With the clothes, she travels regularly to buy them by the dozen according to how the sales are going. The loans that she has received from the Foundation have made her business grow. She pays for all of the Yanbal and Avon up front and they let her get the clothes on credit, paying according to how the sales are. By the same token, she gives her customers easy payment options. With this new loan that she is asking for, she will be able to buy more merchandise and also help her husband with his business. Her husband sells cell phone accessories such as as cases and chargers, in addition to TV remotes. Jessenia's dream is to finish her studies to become a nursery school teacher. She is convinced that she can make it a reality. She really likes to work with children and from 8 in the morning until 4 in the afternoon she is in the nursery school. Her children are with her all the time. She is happy with what she is doing to help her family get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothes and cosmetics and to help her husband with his cell phone accessory business.

loans.name: Mrs. Sok Khoeun Thy Village Bank Group

texts.en: Eleven people from Cheung Prey village in Kandal province make up this group loan. Mrs. S. Khoeun T. is the village bank president. She was selected by all the members, who will use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. S. Khoeun T. is a house wife who cooks delicious food for her children and her husband, Mr. Savoeurn S., who is a motorbike taxi driver. Although they try to work hard they are currently earning less income because their motorbike is broken. So to improve her family's living conditions, Mrs. S. Khoeun T. is seeking a loan to fix her motorbike. She is a mother of two children who are too young to work or study.

loans.use: To fix her motorbike.

loans.name: Madinahon's Group

texts.en:
Madinahon T. is the leader of this group. She is twenty seven and has a one–year-old son. To provide for the family her husband works as a taxi driver. He earns 43 to 45$ a month. Madinahon has a small farm with ten cows, five calves and thirty sheep. She also works at the local school as a math teacher. Madinahon has been familiar with cattle breeding since her childhood and, after getting married, this skill greatly helped her family with extra funds. Madinahon’s monthly income is around $110. During the past few years, she has managed to increase her livestock, make repairs to her house, and buy a car. With this loan Madinahon plans to purchase cattle forage and a cell phone. 

Madinahon’s partners: 

O. Zulfiya, 34, has three children. Her husband is disabled and has a pension. To provide for the family, Zulfiya grows cotton and does odd jobs, which brings her $2.50 per day. Zulfiya has applied for this loan to purchase mineral and nitric fertilizers.

Marhabo T., 32, is a mother of three children. Her husband works as a taxi driver. Marhabo breeds cattle and spends fall and spring in pastures looking after them. She also sells milk products. Now, Marhabo needs a loan to purchase two cows. 

Mavludahon M., 29, has three children. Her husband is among those who have left the country in search of work. He is now working in Russia as a builder. Mavludahon does odd jobs and also has an allowance. She needs this loan for repair works in the house. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle forage and a cell phone

loans.name: Tom

texts.en:
Tom is 38 years old. He is married with 5 children between the ages of 4 and 17. All the children are currently attending school. He is a farmer from Kitale town in Western Kenya where he has been farming for 20 years. His products are maize and milk which he sells locally. He also owns a posho mill (making cornmeal) and a power saw for lumbering. His biggest challenge in farming has been the high prices of dairy feed and animal diseases which affect trade.

He has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for 31,200 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. Through the sale of milk from this dairy cow, Tom will be able to increase his sources of income which will enable him to meet the family's basic needs.

He is grateful to Juhudi for uplifting the lives of small-scale farmers.

loans.use: To purchase and insure  a dairy cow

loans.name: Sonia Del Socorro

texts.es:
Doña Sonia es una mujer activa, trabajadora, con un  hijo de dos años, vive  en el  bario de la capital de Managua, Máximo Jerez.
Su negocio es una pulpería que desde hace cinco  años vende.
El cual comenzó con dinero de liquidación de su trabajo en zona franca.
Ambos su esposo el cual se ha esforzado para que su negocio aumente y lograr obtener mejores entradas económicas.

Su esposo se encarga de las ventas de tortilla el cual pagan a una joven que palmee las ricas tortillas que se venden en su misma casa.
Con este préstamo invertirá en la compra de granos básicos como: quintal de frijoles, arroz, maíz, azúcar, bidón de aceite, potes de leche, papel higiénico, gaseosas, golosinas entre otros productos consumibles. 
Logrando así mejores ventas, clientes nuevos, mejor atención. Que gracias al financiamiento lograra el objetivo de aumentar su inventario.
texts.en:
Doña Sonia is an active and very hard-working woman with a 2 year old son. She lives in a suburb of the capital Managua, Máximo Jerez. She has a small grocery store which she has had for 5 years. Sonia began this business with money from a clearance sale from her work in the duty-free zone. Both Sonia and her husband have worked hard to grow the business and obtain better economic earnings. Sonia's husband takes charge of selling tortillas, and pays a young helper to form the delicious tortillas that they sell in their own home. With this loan they will invest in the purchase of basic grains such as: sacks of beans, rice, maize, sugar, cans of oil, jars of milk, toilet paper, soft drinks, and lollies, among other comestible products. In this way they hope to obtain better sales, new clients and better patronage. Thanks to this finance Sonia will achieve the objective of expanding her inventory.

Translated from Spanish by Jane McCrory, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase basic grains, lollies, soft drinks, and milk to expand inventory

loans.name: Anis' Group

texts.en:
Anis lives Lahore, Pakistan, which is very famous for its history and architecture. To help her husband support their family, she sells ready-made clothes which she orders from different suppliers. She started this business last year, after receiving her first loan from Asasah, and is happy to report that her small company is doing very well. Anis would like to continue helping her husband, who makes a living as a printer. He recently received a large order and needs to buy toner and paper to complete it. She has applied for this loan to allow him to buy these supplies. We believe she will pay the loan back because she has a strong record of making payments on time and has never missed a meeting of our organization.

Note: In this photo of her loan group, we see one of the embroidered dresses she has made.

loans.use: To buy supplies for a printing business

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina E. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is 49 years old. To make a living, Rosalina owns & operates a business planting & harvesting corn for sale. Rosalina is working hard to make her farm productive and to earn more.

Rosalina joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosalina has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Rosalina is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure and other farm inputs. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Rosalina from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to their house. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: By God’S Grace Group

texts.en:
Sando M., who is holding the sign in the photo, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called By God’s Grace. Sando is 48 years old, married and has six children who range from 6 to 24 years old. She was not able to attend school due to lack of financial support. For 2 years, she has been operating a mini restaurant in Barnard Farm Community on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia.

She plans to use her 5,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 25,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more bags of rice, gallons of oil, peppers, meat, fish, onions, etc. She describes herself a determined woman.

Her dream is to grow her business and continue to support her children so that they can have a better future.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, gallons of oil, peppers, meat, fish, onions etc

loans.name: Vestine

texts.en:
Vestine is 42 years old, married to a driver, and has six children. Her children are between the ages of three and twenty-two. Five of her children are in school while the youngest is not yet of school age.
Vestine's business is well-known because she sells crops that are in high demand in her homestead, such as tomatoes. She is requesting a loan to buy more products for her store because she hopes to make more profit given more capital.

loans.use: To buy more crops to fill her store

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul has been practicing mixed farming in Kisii town, western Kenya for 25 years. His farm produces bananas, beans, maize, milk, and tea which he sells locally and through Kenya Tea Development Authority. He is also employed as a casual laborer. He is 49 years old and married with six children between the ages of six and 22. Four of the children attend school.

He recently repaid his previous loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 35,000KES and has requested 50,000KES to engage in horticultural farming. He mainly wants to specialize in tomatoes farming. He says the income from this loan will help him pay school fees for his children and improve his family's standard of living. In future, he plans to acquire a van to help him transport produce from the farm to the market. His primary challenges are fluctuation in the price of milk, market competition, changes in weather conditions, diseases and transportation problems.

loans.use: To engage in horticultural farming.

loans.name: Burulbubu's Group

texts.en:
Burulbubu B. is the leader of the group. She is 37 and a widow. She has raised two sons and a daughter. All the children attend school. Burulbubu works as a social worker and receives a monthly salary in the amount of 3600 soms. She is also engaged in cattle breeding. She applied for the loan because she needs money to improve her living conditions and purchase household appliances. 

Aikul J. is the treasurer of the group. She is 45 and married. Her husband works in construction and earns 8000 soms per month. They have four sons. The two older sons are working in construction and the other sons are at school. Aikul hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to purchase wood to start repairing the house. In the future she wants to purchase a house in Bishkek.

Sezim M. is 21. She works in a sewing workshop. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase cement to start repairing the house.

Liza T., 34, is married. She has three daughters and two sons. Her husband is handicapped, so Liza earns money to cover family expenses by herself. She is engaged in cattle breeding. She makes 3000 soms per month reselling cattle after fattening. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase hay for cattle.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase household appliances

loans.name: María Benilda

texts.es:
En la ciudadela Cevallos de la ciudad de Portoviejo se reúne cada quince días el Banco Comunal Damas De Éxito, esta es una zona urbano marginal muy poblada en esta ciudad.

La señora María es socia fundadora del Banco Comunal y le gusta por el apoyo que le brindan  tanto a ella como a sus amigas con los créditos, además que los créditos son fáciles de conseguir sin tantos requisitos. Ella tiene 56 años de edad, en la actualidad está soltera y tuvo 4 hijos de una relación que tuvo hace muchos años, los mismos que ya son mayores de edad, dos de ellos viven con ella.

Se dedica a la fabricación y venta de llaves, tiene un pequeño taller en el centro de la ciudad donde día  a día realiza su trabajo el cual empieza a las 8am y lo mantiene abierto hasta las 18h00, trabaja sola y en ciertas ocasiones uno de sus hijos le ayuda,  nos cuenta que todos los días llegan muchos clientes hasta su local a que les realice su trabajo.

Este crédito es para comprar materia prima para la fabricación de las llaves. Sus sueños son tener un taller con mayor infraestructura y gozar de buena salud.
texts.en:
The 'Damas de Éxito' (Successful Ladies) community bank meets every two weeks in the Cevallos neighborhood of the city of Portoviejo.  This is a very densely-populated, marginal, urban area of the city.

María is a founding member of the community bank and she likes the support which it gives both her and her friends through its loans.  What is more, the loans are easy to access without so many requirements.  María is 56 years old and is currently single.  She has 4 children from a relationship which she had a long time ago.  Her children are now grown up and two of them live with her.

María makes and sells keys.  She has a small workshop in the city center where she carries out her work every day.  She starts work at 8.00am and stays open until 6.00pm.  She works alone and sometimes one of her sons helps her.  She tells us that she has a lot of customers coming to her store every day for her services.

This loan will be used to buy raw material for making keys.  Her dreams are to have a workshop with better infrastructure and to continue in good health.

loans.use: To buy raw material to make keys

loans.name: Mujeres Emprendedoras Group

texts.es: Doña Maruca P. V., tiene 38 D. edad, es una señora casada  con dos hijos, 1 niña D. 9 años y 1 nena especial D. cuatro años Doña Maruca, trata D. apoyar económicamente a su familia y darle un mejor futuro a sus hijos, ella se dedica a la venta D. telas para elaborar güipiles y blusas, actividad que ha venido realizando desD. hace más D. 10 años, doña Maruca se dio cuenta que necesitaba comprar y surtir su venta y así poder obtener dinero  por esa razón ella quiere, mejorar las ventas y así obtener un poco mas D. ganancias, ella cada día sale a vender en diferentes lugares como también ella venD. en los días D. plaza del pueblo, ella es madre soltera, no tiene el apoyo D. su esposo y con su niña trabaja para darle lo mejor, por lo cual ella reunió a algunas señoras que conocía desD. hace mas D. 10 años para poder conformar un grupo, es el segundo crédito que solicitan a esta institución, no solo apoya a su familia si no que también a las personas D. su aldea. Cada una D. las señoras  se dedican a diferentes actividades tales como: venta D. frutas, crianza D. animales, venta D. ropa, venta D. utensilios,  entre otros. El préstamo lo utilizará para comprar hilo y tela para elaborar los güipiles y las blusas, con lo que espera obtener mejores ingresos y mejorar su condición D. vida.
texts.en: Maruca P. V., 38, is a married woman with 2 children: a daughter 9 years of age and a special little girl who is 4 years old.  Maruca tries to support her family economically and proviD. a better future for her children.  She sells fabric that is used to make shirts and traditional Guatemalan blouses.  She has been doing this kind of work for more than 10 years.  Maruca realized that she needed to make purchases to stock her business so that she could make money; accordingly, she wants to increase her sales and in this way have a little bit more income.  She sells every day in different places and she also sells in her village on market days.  She is a single mother who does not have the support of a husband, and she works so that she can proviD. the best for her daughter.  To do this, she met with some women that she had known for over 10 years so that they could form a group.  This is the second loan that they have requested from this institution, which not only supports their families but also other people in their town.  Each of these women is devoted to a different activity such as: selling fruit, raising livestock, selling clothing, selling utensils, and others.  This loan will be used to purchase the thread and fabric that are used to make traditional Guatemalan blouses and shirts.  With the loan, she hopes to improve her income and improve her standard of living.

loans.use: working capital: to buy fabric and thread to make garments

loans.name: Sara Maria

texts.es:
Sonia de 52 años, vende ropa su esposo es taxista y tienen dos hijos. Vive en una zona periurbana ubicada a las afuera de Guayaquil llamada Duran y caracterizada por su ecología de disolución.    

Para ayudarle a su esposo con los gastos de la casa ella empezó a trabajar vendiendo ropa por catalogo. Poco a poco incremento su cartera de clientes con la ayuda de que conocia a mucha gente del sector donde vive. Vende blusas, camisas, pantalones, ropa interior muy economica por catalogo (los catalogos apararecen en la foto) en ocaciones le da a sus clientes creditos en la ropa para que tengan mas facilidad de pago.  

Con el préstamo quiere comprar ropa para tener mas variedad en sus ventas. En el futuro quiere terminar de construir su casa de cemento ya que era uno de los sueños del esposo.
texts.en:
Sonia is 52 years old.  She sells clothes.  Her husband is a taxi driver and they have two children.  She lives in a peri-urban area on the outskirts of Guayaquil called Duran which is noted for its deteriorating ecosystem.

To help her husband with their household expenses, Sonia started selling clothes through catalogs.  Little by little she increased her customer base, helped by the fact that she knew a lot of people in her area.  She sells very reasonably priced blouses, shirts, pants and underwear from her catalogs (which appear in the photo).  Sometimes she gives her customers the clothes on credit so that they can pay more easily.

She would like to use this loan to buy clothes so that she has more variety in what she sells.  In the future, she would like to finish building her house from cement as this was one of her husband's dreams.

loans.use: To buy clothes

loans.name: Soliatou L. I.

texts.fr: Âgée de 33 ans, Soliatou est mariée et a 3 enfants. Elle vit avec son mari et les enfants sont tous scolarisés. Elle participe aux différentes charges du foyer. Elle a 8 ans d'expérience dans son domaine. Elle commercialise les produits alimentaires tels que les sardines, les tomates en boîtes, les boites de nescafé, les cartons de sucres, du lait en poudre ou concentré. Ses clients sont constitués des ménages de la zone et de ses environs. Elle s'approvisionne chez les grossistes à Tokpa, le plus grand marché du Bénin et au Togo ou au Nigeria, deux pays frontaliers au Bénin. Dans le souci d'une meilleure satisfaction de sa clientèle, elle a sollicité et obtenu un 1er crédit à FINADEV pour bien ravitailler sa boutique en ces divers produits d'alimentation. Le revenu supplémentaire généré par le micro crédit lui permettra de mieux faire aux charges du foyer afin de faire souffler un tout petit peu son mari au foyer. Elle souhaiterait avoir sa propre maison de distribution de gros des alimentaires et avoir sa propre maison pour quitter la location.
texts.en:
Soliatou, aged 33, is married and has 3 children. She lives with her husband and children who all attend school. 
She takes part in covering the family's various expenses. She has 8 years of experience in her field. She sells food products such as sardines, canned tomatoes, boxes of Nescafé (instant coffee), boxes of sugar, powdered or concentrated milk. Her client base is made up of households in the neighborhood and its outskirts. She gets her supplies from wholesalers at Tokpa, Benin’s largest market, and in Togo or Nigeria, two bordering countries. 
With the goal of better satisfying her customers, she requested and obtained a first loan from FINADEV to stock up her shop on these various food products. 
The extra income generated by the micro-loan will enable her to better meet household expenses and thus allow her husband to get a little rest at home. She would like to have her own wholesale food distribution business as well as her own house to stop renting.

loans.use: To stock up on food products (sardines, canned tomatoes, boxes of Nescafé (instant coffee), boxes of sugar, powdered or concentrated milk) to meet customer needs

loans.name: Hermenita

texts.en:
Hermenita J. is from the village of Malinao, Kalilangan, Bukidnon. She is 24 years old. Hermenita is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Hermenita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop.
